name: Kepler-225
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-225 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-225 is a star with 0.3799999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.48 times its radius. It is located 1859.06 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-225 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-225 b

Kepler-225 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.74 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-225.

The mass of Kepler-225 b is 1.49 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-225 b is 1.2 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-225 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-225 c

Kepler-225 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 18.79 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-225.

The mass of Kepler-225 c is 4.15 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-225 c is 1.84 that of Earth. At 4.15 Earth masses, Kepler-225 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-225, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
